We are Hiring for Below Roles. 100% Remote and Contract Role. Need 12+ years of experience Over all for all the Roles. Kindly Drop your resume to naveen@lorventech.comLorven Technologies Inc.Job Description 1: Data Engineer We are seeking a Data Engineer with deep understanding of database systems and experience in data management and analysis. The ideal candidate will be proficient in programming languages such as Python, Java, or SQL for data manipulation and analysis. Experience with relational database management systems (RDBMS) such as MySQL, Oracle, or PostgreSQL is a must, as well as familiarity with NoSQL databases like MongoDB or Cassandra. The candidate should be skilled in using data analysis tools and platforms, such as Excel, R, or MATLAB and be adept at using data visualization tools like Tableau, Power BI, or D3.js. Experience in the Risk systems for Banks would be a plus.  Job Description 2: Data Integration Specialist We are looking for a Data Integration Specialist to join our team. The candidate should have knowledge of Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) processes and tools like Apache NiFi, Talend, or Informatica. Experience with data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is required. Proficiency in scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell) for automation of data processes is a must. The role will involve working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any relevant experience would be advantageous.  Job Description 3: Data QA Engineer As a Data QA Engineer is needed to join our team. The ideal candidate will have skills in writing and executing test cases for both production and non-production environments. Familiarity with automated testing frameworks and tools like Selenium, JUnit is required. An understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services is a plus. The candidate will also be involved in risk management and anti-money laundering projects, so experience in these areas, particularly in the banking sector, is beneficial.  Job Description 4: Cloud Computing Specialist We are seeking a Cloud Computing Specialist with an understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services. The candidate should have proficiency in programming languages such as Python, Java, or SQL and experience with scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell). Familiarity with database management systems and data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is important. The role involves working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any experience in these areas would be a plus.

Kindly Drop your resume to naveen@lorventech.comLorven Technologies Inc.Job Description 1: Data Engineer We are seeking a Data Engineer with deep understanding of database systems and experience in data management and analysis. The ideal candidate will be proficient in programming languages such as Python, Java, or SQL for data manipulation and analysis. Experience with relational database management systems (RDBMS) such as MySQL, Oracle, or PostgreSQL is a must, as well as familiarity with NoSQL databases like MongoDB or Cassandra. Experience in the Risk systems for Banks would be a plus.  Job Description 2: Data Integration Specialist We are looking for a Data Integration Specialist to join our team. The candidate should have knowledge of Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) processes and tools like Apache NiFi, Talend, or Informatica. Experience with data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is required. Proficiency in scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell) for automation of data processes is a must. The role will involve working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any relevant experience would be advantageous.  Job Description 3: Data QA Engineer As a Data QA Engineer is needed to join our team. The ideal candidate will have skills in writing and executing test cases for both production and non-production environments. Familiarity with automated testing frameworks and tools like Selenium, JUnit is required. An understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services is a plus. The candidate will also be involved in risk management and anti-money laundering projects, so experience in these areas, particularly in the banking sector, is beneficial.  Job Description 4: Cloud Computing Specialist We are seeking a Cloud Computing Specialist with an understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services. The candidate should have proficiency in programming languages such as Python, Java, or SQL and experience with scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell). Familiarity with database management systems and data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is important. The role involves working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any experience in these areas would be a plus.

Kindly Drop your resume to naveen@lorventech.comLorven Technologies Inc.Job Description 1: Data Engineer We are seeking a Data Engineer with deep understanding of database systems and experience in data management and analysis. The ideal candidate will be proficient in programming languages such as Python, Java, or SQL for data manipulation and analysis. The candidate should be skilled in using data analysis tools and platforms, such as Excel, R, or MATLAB and be adept at using data visualization tools like Tableau, Power BI, or D3.js. Experience in the Risk systems for Banks would be a plus.  Job Description 2: Data Integration Specialist We are looking for a Data Integration Specialist to join our team. The candidate should have knowledge of Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) processes and tools like Apache NiFi, Talend, or Informatica. Experience with data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is required. Proficiency in scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell) for automation of data processes is a must. The role will involve working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any relevant experience would be advantageous.  Job Description 3: Data QA Engineer As a Data QA Engineer is needed to join our team. The ideal candidate will have skills in writing and executing test cases for both production and non-production environments. Familiarity with automated testing frameworks and tools like Selenium, JUnit is required. An understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services is a plus. The candidate will also be involved in risk management and anti-money laundering projects, so experience in these areas, particularly in the banking sector, is beneficial.  Job Description 4: Cloud Computing Specialist We are seeking a Cloud Computing Specialist with an understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services. The candidate should have proficiency in programming languages such as Python, Java, or SQL and experience with scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell). Familiarity with database management systems and data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is important. The role involves working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any experience in these areas would be a plus.

We are Hiring for Below Roles. 100% Remote and Contract Role. Need 12+ years of experience Over all for all the Roles. Kindly Drop your resume to naveen@lorventech.comLorven Technologies Inc.Job Description 1: Data Engineer We are seeking a Data Engineer with deep understanding of database systems and experience in data management and analysis. The ideal candidate will be proficient in programming languages such as Python, Java, or SQL for data manipulation and analysis. Experience with relational database management systems (RDBMS) such as MySQL, Oracle, or PostgreSQL is a must, as well as familiarity with NoSQL databases like MongoDB or Cassandra. The candidate should be skilled in using data analysis tools and platforms, such as Excel, R, or MATLAB and be adept at using data visualization tools like Tableau, Power BI, or D3.js. Experience in the Risk systems for Banks would be a plus.  Job Description 2: Data Integration Specialist We are looking for a Data Integration Specialist to join our team. The candidate should have knowledge of Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) processes and tools like Apache NiFi, Talend, or Informatica. Experience with data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is required. Proficiency in scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell) for automation of data processes is a must. The role will involve working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any relevant experience would be advantageous.  Job Description 3: Data QA Engineer As a Data QA Engineer is needed to join our team. The ideal candidate will have skills in writing and executing test cases for both production and non-production environments. Familiarity with automated testing frameworks and tools like Selenium, JUnit is required. An understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services is a plus. The candidate will also be involved in risk management and anti-money laundering projects, so experience in these areas, particularly in the banking sector, is beneficial.  Job Description 4: Cloud Computing Specialist We are seeking a Cloud Computing Specialist with an understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services. The candidate should have proficiency in programming languages such as Python, Java, or SQL and experience with scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell). Familiarity with database management systems and data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is important. The role involves working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any experience in these areas would be a plus.

We are Hiring for Below Roles. 100% Remote and Contract Role. Need 12+ years of experience Over all for all the Roles. Kindly Drop your resume to naveen@lorventech.comLorven Technologies Inc.Job Description 1: Data Engineer We are seeking a Data Engineer with deep understanding of database systems and experience in data management and analysis. The ideal candidate will be proficient in programming languages such as Python, Java, or SQL for data manipulation and analysis. Experience with relational database management systems (RDBMS) such as MySQL, Oracle, or PostgreSQL is a must, as well as familiarity with NoSQL databases like MongoDB or Cassandra. The candidate should be skilled in using data analysis tools and platforms, such as Excel, R, or MATLAB and be adept at using data visualization tools like Tableau, Power BI, or D3.js. Experience in the Risk systems for Banks would be a plus.  Job Description 2: Data Integration Specialist We are looking for a Data Integration Specialist to join our team. The candidate should have knowledge of Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) processes and tools like Apache NiFi, Talend, or Informatica. Experience with data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is required. Proficiency in scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell) for automation of data processes is a must. The role will involve working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any relevant experience would be advantageous.  Job Description 3: Data QA Engineer As a Data QA Engineer is needed to join our team. The ideal candidate will have skills in writing and executing test cases for both production and non-production environments. Familiarity with automated testing frameworks and tools like Selenium, JUnit is required. An understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services is a plus. The candidate will also be involved in risk management and anti-money laundering projects, so experience in these areas, particularly in the banking sector, is beneficial.  Job Description 4: Cloud Computing Specialist We are seeking a Cloud Computing Specialist with an understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services. The candidate should have proficiency in programming languages such as Python, Java, or SQL and experience with scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell). Familiarity with database management systems and data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is important. The role involves working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any experience in these areas would be a plus.

We are Hiring for Below Roles. 100% Remote and Contract Role. Need 12+ years of experience Over all for all the Roles. Kindly Drop your resume to naveen@lorventech.comLorven Technologies Inc.Job Description 1: Data Engineer We are seeking a Data Engineer with deep understanding of database systems and experience in data management and analysis. The ideal candidate will be proficient in programming languages such as Python, Java, or SQL for data manipulation and analysis. Experience with relational database management systems (RDBMS) such as MySQL, Oracle, or PostgreSQL is a must, as well as familiarity with NoSQL databases like MongoDB or Cassandra. The candidate should be skilled in using data analysis tools and platforms, such as Excel, R, or MATLAB and be adept at using data visualization tools like Tableau, Power BI, or D3.js. Experience in the Risk systems for Banks would be a plus.  Job Description 2: Data Integration Specialist We are looking for a Data Integration Specialist to join our team. The candidate should have knowledge of Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) processes and tools like Apache NiFi, Talend, or Informatica. Experience with data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is required. Proficiency in scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell) for automation of data processes is a must. The role will involve working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any relevant experience would be advantageous.  Job Description 3: Data QA Engineer As a Data QA Engineer is needed to join our team. The ideal candidate will have skills in writing and executing test cases for both production and non-production environments. Familiarity with automated testing frameworks and tools like Selenium, JUnit is required. An understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services is a plus. The candidate will also be involved in risk management and anti-money laundering projects, so experience in these areas, particularly in the banking sector, is beneficial.  Job Description 4: Cloud Computing Specialist We are seeking a Cloud Computing Specialist with an understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services. What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

ğŸ”Day 28 of 100 | API Testing & HTTP Status CodesWhile diving deeper into API testing at SkillShikshya, I encountered an Internal Server Error (500) that sparked my curiosity. ğŸ§ ğŸ’¡ It led me down a rabbit hole to understand what different HTTP status codes really mean â€” and why they're so important for both testers and developers.ğŸ“˜ Here's what I explored:âœ… 1xx â€“ Informational These are provisional responses. The server has received the request and is continuing the process.âœ… 2xx â€“ Success Everything worked perfectly! Common codes include:200 OK: The request succeeded.201 Created: A new resource has been created.âœ… 3xx â€“ Redirection The client must take additional action to complete the request.301 Moved Permanently302 Foundâœ… 4xx â€“ Client Errors Thereâ€™s likely something wrong with the request:400 Bad Request: The server couldnâ€™t understand the request.401 Unauthorized: Authentication is required.403 Forbidden: You donâ€™t have permission.404 Not Found: The resource doesnâ€™t exist.âœ… 5xx â€“ Server Errors The server failed to fulfill a valid request.500 Internal Server Error: Generic server error.502 Bad Gateway, 503 Service Unavailable, etc.ğŸ’¬ Understanding these codes is like learning the language of APIsâ€”it helps pinpoint whatâ€™s going wrong, why, and where to start debugging.This small error opened up a big learning opportunity, reminding me that every bug or failure is a chance to grow. ğŸš€hashtag#100DaysOfLearning hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#APITesting hashtag#QA hashtag#LearningInPublic ğŸ” hashtag#Day28OfLearning | API Testing & HTTP Status CodesWhile diving deeper into API testing, I encountered an Internal Server Error (500) that sparked my curiosity. ğŸ§ ğŸ’¡ It led me down a rabbit hole to understand what different HTTP status codes really mean â€” and why they're so important for both testers and developers.ğŸ“˜ Here's what I explored:âœ… 1xx â€“ Informational These are provisional responses. What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

Job Description 3: Data QA Engineer As a Data QA Engineer is needed to join our team. The ideal candidate will have skills in writing and executing test cases for both production and non-production environments. Familiarity with automated testing frameworks and tools like Selenium, JUnit is required. An understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services is a plus. The candidate will also be involved in risk management and anti-money laundering projects, so experience in these areas, particularly in the banking sector, is beneficial.  Job Description 4: Cloud Computing Specialist We are seeking a Cloud Computing Specialist with an understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services. The candidate should have proficiency in programming languages such as Python, Java, or SQL and experience with scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell). Familiarity with database management systems and data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is important. The role involves working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any experience in these areas would be a plus.

What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

The candidate should have knowledge of Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) processes and tools like Apache NiFi, Talend, or Informatica. Experience with data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is required. Proficiency in scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell) for automation of data processes is a must. The role will involve working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any relevant experience would be advantageous.  Job Description 3: Data QA Engineer As a Data QA Engineer is needed to join our team. The ideal candidate will have skills in writing and executing test cases for both production and non-production environments. Familiarity with automated testing frameworks and tools like Selenium, JUnit is required. An understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services is a plus. The candidate will also be involved in risk management and anti-money laundering projects, so experience in these areas, particularly in the banking sector, is beneficial.  Job Description 4: Cloud Computing Specialist We are seeking a Cloud Computing Specialist with an understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services. The candidate should have proficiency in programming languages such as Python, Java, or SQL and experience with scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell). Familiarity with database management systems and data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is important. The role involves working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any experience in these areas would be a plus.

ğŸ”Day 28 of 100 | API Testing & HTTP Status CodesWhile diving deeper into API testing at SkillShikshya, I encountered an Internal Server Error (500) that sparked my curiosity. ğŸ§ ğŸ’¡ It led me down a rabbit hole to understand what different HTTP status codes really mean â€” and why they're so important for both testers and developers.ğŸ“˜ Here's what I explored:âœ… 1xx â€“ Informational These are provisional responses. The server has received the request and is continuing the process.âœ… 2xx â€“ Success Everything worked perfectly! Common codes include:200 OK: The request succeeded.201 Created: A new resource has been created.âœ… 3xx â€“ Redirection The client must take additional action to complete the request.301 Moved Permanently302 Foundâœ… 4xx â€“ Client Errors Thereâ€™s likely something wrong with the request:400 Bad Request: The server couldnâ€™t understand the request.401 Unauthorized: Authentication is required.403 Forbidden: You donâ€™t have permission.404 Not Found: The resource doesnâ€™t exist.âœ… 5xx â€“ Server Errors The server failed to fulfill a valid request.500 Internal Server Error: Generic server error.502 Bad Gateway, 503 Service Unavailable, etc.ğŸ’¬ Understanding these codes is like learning the language of APIsâ€”it helps pinpoint whatâ€™s going wrong, why, and where to start debugging.This small error opened up a big learning opportunity, reminding me that every bug or failure is a chance to grow. ğŸš€hashtag#100DaysOfLearning hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#APITesting hashtag#QA hashtag#LearningInPublic ğŸ” hashtag#Day28OfLearning | API Testing & HTTP Status CodesWhile diving deeper into API testing, I encountered an Internal Server Error (500) that sparked my curiosity. ğŸ§ ğŸ’¡ It led me down a rabbit hole to understand what different HTTP status codes really mean â€” and why they're so important for both testers and developers.ğŸ“˜ Here's what I explored:âœ… 1xx â€“ Informational These are provisional responses. What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

Just wrote codes for students: Maintaining hydration in Agri-field. void setup(){ Serial.begin(9600); pinMode(11,INPUT);//Sensor pinMode(2,OUTPUT);//Buzzer pinMode(5,OUTPUT);//Motor pinMode(6,OUTPUT);//LED}void loop(){ int p; p=digitalRead(11); Serail.println(p);  if(p==1) { digitalWrite(2,HIGH); digitalWrite(5,LOW); digitalWrite(6,LOW); Serial.println("Moisture is High"); Serial.println("Pump is swtiched OFF"); } else { digitalWrite(2,LOW); digitalWrite(5,HIGH); digitalWrite(6,HIGH); Serial.println("Moisture is Low"); Serial.println("Switch ON Pump"); } delay(10); }

REST APIs: The Unsung Heroes of the Internet ğŸ¦¸â€â™‚ï¸Ever wonder how your favorite apps talk to each other behind the scenes? It's not magicâ€”it's REST APIs!Think of REST APIs as the friendly neighborhood translators of the internet. They're why your weather app knows it's raining, your food delivery app knows where your burger is, and your banking app knows how much money you've spent on coffee this month (no judgment here).Why I'm secretly in love with REST APIs:They're like LEGO blocks for the internetâ€”snap different services together and build something amazingThey speak the universal language of HTTP (GET me a coffee, POST my thoughts on LinkedIn)They're the reason you can book a flight, order dinner, and check your email without switching devicesThey don't hold grudges or remember past conversations (they're stateless, which is actually a good thing!)My favorite part? When someone asks what I do, I can say "I work with REST APIs" and sound both incredibly technical and like I need a nap. Win-win!Anyone else find themselves explaining APIs at parties only to watch everyone suddenly remember they need another drink? ğŸ˜‚hashtag#TechHumor hashtag#APIlife hashtag#DeveloperProblems hashtag#TheInternetIsMagic hashtag#RESTforSuccess

The server has received the request and is continuing the process.âœ… 2xx â€“ Success Everything worked perfectly! Common codes include:200 OK: The request succeeded.201 Created: A new resource has been created.âœ… 3xx â€“ Redirection The client must take additional action to complete the request.301 Moved Permanently302 Foundâœ… 4xx â€“ Client Errors Thereâ€™s likely something wrong with the request:400 Bad Request: The server couldnâ€™t understand the request.401 Unauthorized: Authentication is required.403 Forbidden: You donâ€™t have permission.404 Not Found: The resource doesnâ€™t exist.âœ… 5xx â€“ Server Errors The server failed to fulfill a valid request.500 Internal Server Error: Generic server error.502 Bad Gateway, 503 Service Unavailable, etc.ğŸ’¬ Understanding these codes is like learning the language of APIsâ€”it helps pinpoint whatâ€™s going wrong, why, and where to start debugging.This small error opened up a big learning opportunity, reminding me that every bug or failure is a chance to grow. ğŸš€hashtag#100DaysOfLearning hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#APITesting hashtag#QA hashtag#LearningInPublic ğŸ” hashtag#Day28OfLearning | API Testing & HTTP Status CodesWhile diving deeper into API testing, I encountered an Internal Server Error (500) that sparked my curiosity. ğŸ§ ğŸ’¡ It led me down a rabbit hole to understand what different HTTP status codes really mean â€” and why they're so important for both testers and developers.ğŸ“˜ Here's what I explored:âœ… 1xx â€“ Informational These are provisional responses. What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

Just wrote codes for students: Maintaining hydration in Agri-field. void setup(){ Serial.begin(9600); pinMode(11,INPUT);//Sensor pinMode(2,OUTPUT);//Buzzer pinMode(5,OUTPUT);//Motor pinMode(6,OUTPUT);//LED}void loop(){ int p; p=digitalRead(11); Serail.println(p);  if(p==1) { digitalWrite(2,HIGH); digitalWrite(5,LOW); digitalWrite(6,LOW); Serial.println("Moisture is High"); Serial.println("Pump is swtiched OFF"); } else { digitalWrite(2,LOW); digitalWrite(5,HIGH); digitalWrite(6,HIGH); Serial.println("Moisture is Low"); Serial.println("Switch ON Pump"); } delay(10); }

REST APIs: The Unsung Heroes of the Internet ğŸ¦¸â€â™‚ï¸Ever wonder how your favorite apps talk to each other behind the scenes? It's not magicâ€”it's REST APIs!Think of REST APIs as the friendly neighborhood translators of the internet. They're why your weather app knows it's raining, your food delivery app knows where your burger is, and your banking app knows how much money you've spent on coffee this month (no judgment here).Why I'm secretly in love with REST APIs:They're like LEGO blocks for the internetâ€”snap different services together and build something amazingThey speak the universal language of HTTP (GET me a coffee, POST my thoughts on LinkedIn)They're the reason you can book a flight, order dinner, and check your email without switching devicesThey don't hold grudges or remember past conversations (they're stateless, which is actually a good thing!)My favorite part? When someone asks what I do, I can say "I work with REST APIs" and sound both incredibly technical and like I need a nap. Win-win!Anyone else find themselves explaining APIs at parties only to watch everyone suddenly remember they need another drink? ğŸ˜‚hashtag#TechHumor hashtag#APIlife hashtag#DeveloperProblems hashtag#TheInternetIsMagic hashtag#RESTforSuccess

What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

Just wrote codes for students: Maintaining hydration in Agri-field. void setup(){ Serial.begin(9600); pinMode(11,INPUT);//Sensor pinMode(2,OUTPUT);//Buzzer pinMode(5,OUTPUT);//Motor pinMode(6,OUTPUT);//LED}void loop(){ int p; p=digitalRead(11); Serail.println(p);  if(p==1) { digitalWrite(2,HIGH); digitalWrite(5,LOW); digitalWrite(6,LOW); Serial.println("Moisture is High"); Serial.println("Pump is swtiched OFF"); } else { digitalWrite(2,LOW); digitalWrite(5,HIGH); digitalWrite(6,HIGH); Serial.println("Moisture is Low"); Serial.println("Switch ON Pump"); } delay(10); }

REST APIs: The Unsung Heroes of the Internet ğŸ¦¸â€â™‚ï¸Ever wonder how your favorite apps talk to each other behind the scenes? It's not magicâ€”it's REST APIs!Think of REST APIs as the friendly neighborhood translators of the internet. They're why your weather app knows it's raining, your food delivery app knows where your burger is, and your banking app knows how much money you've spent on coffee this month (no judgment here).Why I'm secretly in love with REST APIs:They're like LEGO blocks for the internetâ€”snap different services together and build something amazingThey speak the universal language of HTTP (GET me a coffee, POST my thoughts on LinkedIn)They're the reason you can book a flight, order dinner, and check your email without switching devicesThey don't hold grudges or remember past conversations (they're stateless, which is actually a good thing!)My favorite part? When someone asks what I do, I can say "I work with REST APIs" and sound both incredibly technical and like I need a nap. Win-win!Anyone else find themselves explaining APIs at parties only to watch everyone suddenly remember they need another drink? ğŸ˜‚hashtag#TechHumor hashtag#APIlife hashtag#DeveloperProblems hashtag#TheInternetIsMagic hashtag#RESTforSuccess

ğŸ”Day 28 of 100 | API Testing & HTTP Status CodesWhile diving deeper into API testing at SkillShikshya, I encountered an Internal Server Error (500) that sparked my curiosity. ğŸ§ ğŸ’¡ It led me down a rabbit hole to understand what different HTTP status codes really mean â€” and why they're so important for both testers and developers.ğŸ“˜ Here's what I explored:âœ… 1xx â€“ Informational These are provisional responses. The server has received the request and is continuing the process.âœ… 2xx â€“ Success Everything worked perfectly! Common codes include:200 OK: The request succeeded.201 Created: A new resource has been created.âœ… 3xx â€“ Redirection The client must take additional action to complete the request.301 Moved Permanently302 Foundâœ… 4xx â€“ Client Errors Thereâ€™s likely something wrong with the request:400 Bad Request: The server couldnâ€™t understand the request.401 Unauthorized: Authentication is required.403 Forbidden: You donâ€™t have permission.404 Not Found: The resource doesnâ€™t exist.âœ… 5xx â€“ Server Errors The server failed to fulfill a valid request.500 Internal Server Error: Generic server error.502 Bad Gateway, 503 Service Unavailable, etc.ğŸ’¬ Understanding these codes is like learning the language of APIsâ€”it helps pinpoint whatâ€™s going wrong, why, and where to start debugging.This small error opened up a big learning opportunity, reminding me that every bug or failure is a chance to grow. ğŸš€hashtag#100DaysOfLearning hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#APITesting hashtag#QA hashtag#LearningInPublic ğŸ” hashtag#Day28OfLearning | API Testing & HTTP Status CodesWhile diving deeper into API testing, I encountered an Internal Server Error (500) that sparked my curiosity. ğŸ§ ğŸ’¡ It led me down a rabbit hole to understand what different HTTP status codes really mean â€” and why they're so important for both testers and developers.ğŸ“˜ Here's what I explored:âœ… 1xx â€“ Informational These are provisional responses. The server has received the request and is continuing the process.âœ… 2xx â€“ Success Everything worked perfectly! Common codes include:200 OK: The request succeeded.201 Created: A new resource has been created.âœ… 3xx â€“ Redirection The client must take additional action to complete the request.301 Moved Permanently302 Foundâœ… 4xx â€“ Client Errors Thereâ€™s likely something wrong with the request:400 Bad Request: The server couldnâ€™t understand the request.401 Unauthorized: Authentication is required.403 Forbidden: You donâ€™t have permission.404 Not Found: The resource doesnâ€™t exist.âœ… 5xx â€“ Server Errors The server failed to fulfill a valid request.500 Internal Server Error: Generic server error.502 Bad Gateway, 503 Service Unavailable, etc.ğŸ’¬ Understanding these codes is like learning the language of APIsâ€”it helps pinpoint whatâ€™s going wrong, why, and where to start debugging.hashtag#100DaysOfLearning hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#APITesting hashtag#QA hashtag#LearningInPublic hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#HTTPStatusCodes hashtag#BugToBreakthrough hashtag#LinkedInLearning

What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

Just wrote codes for students: Maintaining hydration in Agri-field. void setup(){ Serial.begin(9600); pinMode(11,INPUT);//Sensor pinMode(2,OUTPUT);//Buzzer pinMode(5,OUTPUT);//Motor pinMode(6,OUTPUT);//LED}void loop(){ int p; p=digitalRead(11); Serail.println(p);  if(p==1) { digitalWrite(2,HIGH); digitalWrite(5,LOW); digitalWrite(6,LOW); Serial.println("Moisture is High"); Serial.println("Pump is swtiched OFF"); } else { digitalWrite(2,LOW); digitalWrite(5,HIGH); digitalWrite(6,HIGH); Serial.println("Moisture is Low"); Serial.println("Switch ON Pump"); } delay(10); }

It's not magicâ€”it's REST APIs!Think of REST APIs as the friendly neighborhood translators of the internet. They're why your weather app knows it's raining, your food delivery app knows where your burger is, and your banking app knows how much money you've spent on coffee this month (no judgment here).Why I'm secretly in love with REST APIs:They're like LEGO blocks for the internetâ€”snap different services together and build something amazingThey speak the universal language of HTTP (GET me a coffee, POST my thoughts on LinkedIn)They're the reason you can book a flight, order dinner, and check your email without switching devicesThey don't hold grudges or remember past conversations (they're stateless, which is actually a good thing!)My favorite part? The role involves working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any experience in these areas would be a plus.

What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

Just wrote codes for students: Maintaining hydration in Agri-field. void setup(){ Serial.begin(9600); pinMode(11,INPUT);//Sensor pinMode(2,OUTPUT);//Buzzer pinMode(5,OUTPUT);//Motor pinMode(6,OUTPUT);//LED}void loop(){ int p; p=digitalRead(11); Serail.println(p);  if(p==1) { digitalWrite(2,HIGH); digitalWrite(5,LOW); digitalWrite(6,LOW); Serial.println("Moisture is High"); Serial.println("Pump is swtiched OFF"); } else { digitalWrite(2,LOW); digitalWrite(5,HIGH); digitalWrite(6,HIGH); Serial.println("Moisture is Low"); Serial.println("Switch ON Pump"); } delay(10); }

REST APIs: The Unsung Heroes of the Internet ğŸ¦¸â€â™‚ï¸Ever wonder how your favorite apps talk to each other behind the scenes? It's not magicâ€”it's REST APIs!Think of REST APIs as the friendly neighborhood translators of the internet. They're why your weather app knows it's raining, your food delivery app knows where your burger is, and your banking app knows how much money you've spent on coffee this month (no judgment here).Why I'm secretly in love with REST APIs:They're like LEGO blocks for the internetâ€”snap different services together and build something amazingThey speak the universal language of HTTP (GET me a coffee, POST my thoughts on LinkedIn)They're the reason you can book a flight, order dinner, and check your email without switching devicesThey don't hold grudges or remember past conversations (they're stateless, which is actually a good thing!)My favorite part? When someone asks what I do, I can say "I work with REST APIs" and sound both incredibly technical and like I need a nap. Win-win!Anyone else find themselves explaining APIs at parties only to watch everyone suddenly remember they need another drink? ğŸ˜‚hashtag#TechHumor hashtag#APIlife hashtag#DeveloperProblems hashtag#TheInternetIsMagic hashtag#RESTforSuccess

Experience with relational database management systems (RDBMS) such as MySQL, Oracle, or PostgreSQL is a must, as well as familiarity with NoSQL databases like MongoDB or Cassandra. The candidate should be skilled in using data analysis tools and platforms, such as Excel, R, or MATLAB and be adept at using data visualization tools like Tableau, Power BI, or D3.js. Experience in the Risk systems for Banks would be a plus.  Job Description 2: Data Integration Specialist We are looking for a Data Integration Specialist to join our team. The candidate should have knowledge of Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) processes and tools like Apache NiFi, Talend, or Informatica. Experience with data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is required. Proficiency in scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell) for automation of data processes is a must. The role will involve working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any relevant experience would be advantageous.  Job Description 3: Data QA Engineer As a Data QA Engineer is needed to join our team. The ideal candidate will have skills in writing and executing test cases for both production and non-production environments. Familiarity with automated testing frameworks and tools like Selenium, JUnit is required. An understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services is a plus. The candidate will also be involved in risk management and anti-money laundering projects, so experience in these areas, particularly in the banking sector, is beneficial.  Job Description 4: Cloud Computing Specialist We are seeking a Cloud Computing Specialist with an understanding of AWS cloud and AWS cloud native services. The candidate should have proficiency in programming languages such as Python, Java, or SQL and experience with scripting languages (e.g., Bash, PowerShell). Familiarity with database management systems and data warehousing solutions such as Amazon Redshift, or Snowflake is important. The role involves working in the Risk and Anti Money laundering (AML) space, so any experience in these areas would be a plus.

What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

Just wrote codes for students: Maintaining hydration in Agri-field. void setup(){ Serial.begin(9600); pinMode(11,INPUT);//Sensor pinMode(2,OUTPUT);//Buzzer pinMode(5,OUTPUT);//Motor pinMode(6,OUTPUT);//LED}void loop(){ int p; p=digitalRead(11); Serail.println(p);  if(p==1) { digitalWrite(2,HIGH); digitalWrite(5,LOW); digitalWrite(6,LOW); Serial.println("Moisture is High"); Serial.println("Pump is swtiched OFF"); } else { digitalWrite(2,LOW); digitalWrite(5,HIGH); digitalWrite(6,HIGH); Serial.println("Moisture is Low"); Serial.println("Switch ON Pump"); } delay(10); }

REST APIs: The Unsung Heroes of the Internet ğŸ¦¸â€â™‚ï¸Ever wonder how your favorite apps talk to each other behind the scenes? It's not magicâ€”it's REST APIs!Think of REST APIs as the friendly neighborhood translators of the internet. They're why your weather app knows it's raining, your food delivery app knows where your burger is, and your banking app knows how much money you've spent on coffee this month (no judgment here).Why I'm secretly in love with REST APIs:They're like LEGO blocks for the internetâ€”snap different services together and build something amazingThey speak the universal language of HTTP (GET me a coffee, POST my thoughts on LinkedIn)They're the reason you can book a flight, order dinner, and check your email without switching devicesThey don't hold grudges or remember past conversations (they're stateless, which is actually a good thing!)My favorite part? When someone asks what I do, I can say "I work with REST APIs" and sound both incredibly technical and like I need a nap. Win-win!Anyone else find themselves explaining APIs at parties only to watch everyone suddenly remember they need another drink? ğŸ˜‚hashtag#TechHumor hashtag#APIlife hashtag#DeveloperProblems hashtag#TheInternetIsMagic hashtag#RESTforSuccess

The server has received the request and is continuing the process.âœ… 2xx â€“ Success Everything worked perfectly! Common codes include:200 OK: The request succeeded.201 Created: A new resource has been created.âœ… 3xx â€“ Redirection The client must take additional action to complete the request.301 Moved Permanently302 Foundâœ… 4xx â€“ Client Errors Thereâ€™s likely something wrong with the request:400 Bad Request: The server couldnâ€™t understand the request.401 Unauthorized: Authentication is required.403 Forbidden: You donâ€™t have permission.404 Not Found: The resource doesnâ€™t exist.âœ… 5xx â€“ Server Errors The server failed to fulfill a valid request.500 Internal Server Error: Generic server error.502 Bad Gateway, 503 Service Unavailable, etc.ğŸ’¬ Understanding these codes is like learning the language of APIsâ€”it helps pinpoint whatâ€™s going wrong, why, and where to start debugging.This small error opened up a big learning opportunity, reminding me that every bug or failure is a chance to grow. ğŸš€hashtag#100DaysOfLearning hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#APITesting hashtag#QA hashtag#LearningInPublic ğŸ” hashtag#Day28OfLearning | API Testing & HTTP Status CodesWhile diving deeper into API testing, I encountered an Internal Server Error (500) that sparked my curiosity. ğŸ§ ğŸ’¡ It led me down a rabbit hole to understand what different HTTP status codes really mean â€” and why they're so important for both testers and developers.ğŸ“˜ Here's what I explored:âœ… 1xx â€“ Informational These are provisional responses. What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

Just wrote codes for students: Maintaining hydration in Agri-field. void setup(){ Serial.begin(9600); pinMode(11,INPUT);//Sensor pinMode(2,OUTPUT);//Buzzer pinMode(5,OUTPUT);//Motor pinMode(6,OUTPUT);//LED}void loop(){ int p; p=digitalRead(11); Serail.println(p);  if(p==1) { digitalWrite(2,HIGH); digitalWrite(5,LOW); digitalWrite(6,LOW); Serial.println("Moisture is High"); Serial.println("Pump is swtiched OFF"); } else { digitalWrite(2,LOW); digitalWrite(5,HIGH); digitalWrite(6,HIGH); Serial.println("Moisture is Low"); Serial.println("Switch ON Pump"); } delay(10); }

REST APIs: The Unsung Heroes of the Internet ğŸ¦¸â€â™‚ï¸Ever wonder how your favorite apps talk to each other behind the scenes? It's not magicâ€”it's REST APIs!Think of REST APIs as the friendly neighborhood translators of the internet. They're why your weather app knows it's raining, your food delivery app knows where your burger is, and your banking app knows how much money you've spent on coffee this month (no judgment here).Why I'm secretly in love with REST APIs:They're like LEGO blocks for the internetâ€”snap different services together and build something amazingThey speak the universal language of HTTP (GET me a coffee, POST my thoughts on LinkedIn)They're the reason you can book a flight, order dinner, and check your email without switching devicesThey don't hold grudges or remember past conversations (they're stateless, which is actually a good thing!)My favorite part? When someone asks what I do, I can say "I work with REST APIs" and sound both incredibly technical and like I need a nap. Win-win!Anyone else find themselves explaining APIs at parties only to watch everyone suddenly remember they need another drink? ğŸ˜‚hashtag#TechHumor hashtag#APIlife hashtag#DeveloperProblems hashtag#TheInternetIsMagic hashtag#RESTforSuccess

ğŸ”Day 28 of 100 | API Testing & HTTP Status CodesWhile diving deeper into API testing at SkillShikshya, I encountered an Internal Server Error (500) that sparked my curiosity. ğŸ§ ğŸ’¡ It led me down a rabbit hole to understand what different HTTP status codes really mean â€” and why they're so important for both testers and developers.ğŸ“˜ Here's what I explored:âœ… 1xx â€“ Informational These are provisional responses. The server has received the request and is continuing the process.âœ… 2xx â€“ Success Everything worked perfectly! Common codes include:200 OK: The request succeeded.201 Created: A new resource has been created.âœ… 3xx â€“ Redirection The client must take additional action to complete the request.301 Moved Permanently302 Foundâœ… 4xx â€“ Client Errors Thereâ€™s likely something wrong with the request:400 Bad Request: The server couldnâ€™t understand the request.401 Unauthorized: Authentication is required.403 Forbidden: You donâ€™t have permission.404 Not Found: The resource doesnâ€™t exist.âœ… 5xx â€“ Server Errors The server failed to fulfill a valid request.500 Internal Server Error: Generic server error.502 Bad Gateway, 503 Service Unavailable, etc.ğŸ’¬ Understanding these codes is like learning the language of APIsâ€”it helps pinpoint whatâ€™s going wrong, why, and where to start debugging.This small error opened up a big learning opportunity, reminding me that every bug or failure is a chance to grow. ğŸš€hashtag#100DaysOfLearning hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#APITesting hashtag#QA hashtag#LearningInPublic ğŸ” hashtag#Day28OfLearning | API Testing & HTTP Status CodesWhile diving deeper into API testing, I encountered an Internal Server Error (500) that sparked my curiosity. ğŸ§ ğŸ’¡ It led me down a rabbit hole to understand what different HTTP status codes really mean â€” and why they're so important for both testers and developers.ğŸ“˜ Here's what I explored:âœ… 1xx â€“ Informational These are provisional responses. Common codes include:200 OK: The request succeeded.201 Created: A new resource has been created.âœ… 3xx â€“ Redirection The client must take additional action to complete the request.301 Moved Permanently302 Foundâœ… 4xx â€“ Client Errors Thereâ€™s likely something wrong with the request:400 Bad Request: The server couldnâ€™t understand the request.401 Unauthorized: Authentication is required.403 Forbidden: You donâ€™t have permission.404 Not Found: The resource doesnâ€™t exist.âœ… 5xx â€“ Server Errors The server failed to fulfill a valid request.500 Internal Server Error: Generic server error.502 Bad Gateway, 503 Service Unavailable, etc.ğŸ’¬ Understanding these codes is like learning the language of APIsâ€”it helps pinpoint whatâ€™s going wrong, why, and where to start debugging.hashtag#100DaysOfLearning hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#APITesting hashtag#QA hashtag#LearningInPublic hashtag#TechJourney hashtag#HTTPStatusCodes hashtag#BugToBreakthrough hashtag#LinkedInLearning

What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

Just wrote codes for students: Maintaining hydration in Agri-field. void setup(){ Serial.begin(9600); pinMode(11,INPUT);//Sensor pinMode(2,OUTPUT);//Buzzer pinMode(5,OUTPUT);//Motor pinMode(6,OUTPUT);//LED}void loop(){ int p; p=digitalRead(11); Serail.println(p);  if(p==1) { digitalWrite(2,HIGH); digitalWrite(5,LOW); digitalWrite(6,LOW); Serial.println("Moisture is High"); Serial.println("Pump is swtiched OFF"); } else { digitalWrite(2,LOW); digitalWrite(5,HIGH); digitalWrite(6,HIGH); Serial.println("Moisture is Low"); Serial.println("Switch ON Pump"); } delay(10); }

REST APIs: The Unsung Heroes of the Internet ğŸ¦¸â€â™‚ï¸Ever wonder how your favorite apps talk to each other behind the scenes? It's not magicâ€”it's REST APIs!Think of REST APIs as the friendly neighborhood translators of the internet. They're why your weather app knows it's raining, your food delivery app knows where your burger is, and your banking app knows how much money you've spent on coffee this month (no judgment here).Why I'm secretly in love with REST APIs:They're like LEGO blocks for the internetâ€”snap different services together and build something amazingThey speak the universal language of HTTP (GET me a coffee, POST my thoughts on LinkedIn)They're the reason you can book a flight, order dinner, and check your email without switching devicesThey don't hold grudges or remember past conversations (they're stateless, which is actually a good thing!)My favorite part? When someone asks what I do, I can say "I work with REST APIs" and sound both incredibly technical and like I need a nap. Win-win!Anyone else find themselves explaining APIs at parties only to watch everyone suddenly remember they need another drink? ğŸ˜‚hashtag#TechHumor hashtag#APIlife hashtag#DeveloperProblems hashtag#TheInternetIsMagic hashtag#RESTforSuccess

ğŸ”Day 28 of 100 | API Testing & HTTP Status CodesWhile diving deeper into API testing at SkillShikshya, I encountered an Internal Server Error (500) that sparked my curiosity. ğŸ§ ğŸ’¡ It led me down a rabbit hole to understand what different HTTP status codes really mean â€” and why they're so important for both testers and developers.ğŸ“˜ Here's what I explored:âœ… 1xx â€“ Informational These are provisional responses. The server has received the request and is continuing the process.âœ… 2xx â€“ Success Everything worked perfectly! Common codes include:200 OK: The request succeeded.201 Created: A new resource has been created.âœ… 3xx â€“ Redirection The client must take additional action to complete the request.301 Moved Permanently302 Foundâœ… 4xx â€“ Client Errors Thereâ€™s likely something wrong with the request:400 Bad Request: The server couldnâ€™t understand the request.401 Unauthorized: Authentication is required.403 Forbidden: You donâ€™t have permission.404 Not Found: The resource doesnâ€™t exist.âœ… 5xx â€“ Server Errors The server failed to fulfill a valid request.500 Internal Server Error: Generic server error.502 Bad Gateway, 503 Service Unavailable, etc.ğŸ’¬ Understanding these codes is like learning the language of APIsâ€”it helps pinpoint whatâ€™s going wrong, why, and where to start debugging.This small error opened up a big learning opportunity, reminding me that every bug or failure is a chance to grow. ğŸš€hashtag#100DaysOfLearning hashtag#SoftwareTesting hashtag#APITesting hashtag#QA hashtag#LearningInPublic ğŸ” hashtag#Day28OfLearning | API Testing & HTTP Status CodesWhile diving deeper into API testing, I encountered an Internal Server Error (500) that sparked my curiosity. ğŸ§ ğŸ’¡ It led me down a rabbit hole to understand what different HTTP status codes really mean â€” and why they're so important for both testers and developers.ğŸ“˜ Here's what I explored:âœ… 1xx â€“ Informational These are provisional responses. What would be more convinient for both parties of offshore contract? Knock for knoc indemnity clause or fault based liability according to civil law concept? Knock for knock clause results in no liability the party would otherwise have under the common law. Each party simply bears consequences of its own loss and damage regardless the fault of other party. If there is no need to prove cause, fault or blame there is less space for dispute.Such clause is getting more popular in offshore contracts worldwide.Are we here ready to change the way of thinking?Would such clause be binding under Polish jurisdiction, and do we need to introduce any exemptions, such as as case of willful misconduct?hashtag#knockforknoc, hashtag#Offshore, hashtag#risks  ğŸš§ğŸ—ï¸ğŸƒğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸â€â¡ï¸

Just wrote codes for students: Maintaining hydration in Agri-field. void setup(){ Serial.begin(9600); pinMode(11,INPUT);//Sensor pinMode(2,OUTPUT);//Buzzer pinMode(5,OUTPUT);//Motor pinMode(6,OUTPUT);//LED}void loop(){ int p; p=digitalRead(11); Serail.println(p);  if(p==1) { digitalWrite(2,HIGH); digitalWrite(5,LOW); digitalWrite(6,LOW); Serial.println("Moisture is High"); Serial.println("Pump is swtiched OFF"); } else { digitalWrite(2,LOW); digitalWrite(5,HIGH); digitalWrite(6,HIGH); Serial.println("Moisture is Low"); Serial.println("Switch ON Pump"); } delay(10); }

REST APIs: The Unsung Heroes of the Internet ğŸ¦¸â€â™‚ï¸Ever wonder how your favorite apps talk to each other behind the scenes? It's not magicâ€”it's REST APIs!Think of REST APIs as the friendly neighborhood translators of the internet. They're why your weather app knows it's raining, your food delivery app knows where your burger is, and your banking app knows how much money you've spent on coffee this month (no judgment here).Why I'm secretly in love with REST APIs:They're like LEGO blocks for the internetâ€”snap different services together and build something amazingThey speak the universal language of HTTP (GET me a coffee, POST my thoughts on LinkedIn)They're the reason you can book a flight, order dinner, and check your email without switching devicesThey don't hold grudges or remember past conversations (they're stateless, which is actually a good thing!)My favorite part? When someone asks what I do, I can say "I work with REST APIs" and sound both incredibly technical and like I need a nap. Win-win!Anyone else find themselves explaining APIs at parties only to watch everyone suddenly remember they need another drink? ğŸ˜‚hashtag#TechHumor hashtag#APIlife hashtag#DeveloperProblems hashtag#TheInternetIsMagic hashtag#RESTforSuccess
